question: Question_03
statement:
For the parameter \emph{α}, consider the linear system:

\begin{align*}
x - y + z &= 2, \\
-2x + y + \alpha z &= -3, \\
x + \alpha y - z &= 1.
\end{align*} Determine when the system has a unique solution, no
solution, or infinitely many solutions. (Don$^{\prime}$t determine the
actual solutions!)
sols:
Let \emph{A} be the augmented matrix, that is,

\[A = \begin{bmatrix}
1 &-1 & 1 &2 \\ 
-2 & 1 & \alpha &-3 \\ 
1 & \alpha & -1 & 1
\end{bmatrix}\]

To begin the row-reduction, we add two multiples of the first line to
the second line and also subtract the first line from the third to
obtain

\[\begin{bmatrix}
1 & -1 & 1 & 2 \\ 
-2 & 1 & \alpha &-3 \\ 
1 & \alpha & -1 & 1
\end{bmatrix} \sim \begin{bmatrix}
1 &-1 & 1 & 2 \\ 
0 & -1 & \alpha+2 & 1 \\ 
0 & \alpha+1 & -2 & -1
\end{bmatrix} \sim \begin{bmatrix}
1 &-1 & 1 & 2 \\ 
0 & 1 & -(\alpha+2) & -1 \\ 
0 & \alpha+1 & -2 & -1
\end{bmatrix}\]

Then, subtract a factor of \emph{(α+2)} times the second row from the
last row and simplify

\begin{align*}
\begin{bmatrix}
1 &-1 & 1 & 2 \\ 
0 & 1 & -(\alpha+2) & -1 \\ 
0 & \alpha+1 & -2 & -1
\end{bmatrix} &\sim \begin{bmatrix}
1 &-1 & 1 & 2 \\ 
0 & 1 & -(\alpha+2) & -1 \\ 
0 & 0 & (-(\alpha+2))(-(\alpha+1))-2 & -1+\alpha+1
\end{bmatrix} \\
&\sim \begin{bmatrix}
1 &-1 & 1 & 2 \\ 
0 & 1 & -(\alpha+2) & -1 \\ 
0 & 0 & \alpha(\alpha+3) & \alpha
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}

We can now investigate what happens for different values of \emph{α}.
Notice that the first line doesn't depend on \emph{α} and so there is
nothing to conclude for the first line. For the second line, \emph{α}
could make one of the terms vanish but there will still be a solution to
that equation if this happens. Therefore, the real power of \emph{α}
comes from the third line. We can distinguish three cases for \emph{α}:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  When \emph{α = 0} the matrix will be \textbackslash{}begin\{bmatrix\}
\end{itemize}

1 \& -1 \& 1 \& 2 \textbackslash{}\textbackslash{} 0 \& 1 \& -2 \& -1
\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{} 0 \& 0 \& 0 \& 0
\textbackslash{}end\{bmatrix\}, and there will be \textbf{infinitely
many solutions}.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  When \emph{α = -3} the matrix will be \textbackslash{}begin\{bmatrix\}
\end{itemize}

1 \& -1 \& 1 \& 2 \textbackslash{}\textbackslash{} 0 \& 1 \& 1 \& -1
\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{} 0 \& 0 \& 0 \& -3
\textbackslash{}end\{bmatrix\}, and there will \textbf{be no solution}.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  When \emph{α} is neither 0 nor -3, there will be a \textbf{unique
  solution}.
\end{itemize}
hints: What is the augmented matrix that corresponds to this problem?

Row-reduce the augmented matrix, then consider special choices for
\emph{α} separately.
